questions.question: Question 1: When is World AIDS day observed?
questions.explanation:
The World AIDS Day is observed on December 1st. The theme for 2021 is 'Ending the HIV 
epidemic: E†uitable Access, Everyone’s Voice'. Option A: The World Tuberculosis Day is on March 24. Option B: The World Cancer Day is on February 4. Option D: The World Malaria Day is on April 25.

questions.question: Question 2: What are the most common modes of transmission of HIV in India in descending order?
questions.explanation:
The most common mode of transmission of HIV in India is heterosexual transmission, followed 
by transplacental and homosexual contact, respectively. The common modes of transmission of HIV are: • Heterosexual (83.7%) • Injecting drug users (5.6%) • Transplacental transmission (3.8 %) • Homosexual (2.5%) • Blood and blood products (0.8%) • ‡nknown (3.6%) 309 
Sold by @itachibot The highest risk of transmission is seen in homosexuals due to the increased risk of abrasions 
during anal sex.

questions.question:
Question 3: Health care workers will re†uire post-exposure prophylaxis after exposure to which of the 
following body fluids of an HIV patient?
questions.explanation:
Health care workers exposed to the menstrual blood of an HIV-positive patient will re†uire 
post-exposure prophylaxis. The risk of transmission of HIV during vaginal intercourse is higher 
when the woman is menstruating. Tears, non-blood-stained saliva, urine, and sweat do not pose a significant risk. Exposure to these 
fluids does not re†uire post-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.question:
Question 4: As per WHO staging of HIV, which of the following HIV-positive patients cannot be classified 
as stage IV?

options.a: A 29-year-old man diagnosed with cerebral toxoplasmosis
options.b: A 56-year-old woman with significant weight loss and muscle wasting
options.c: A 43-year-old lady being treated for Pneumocystis pneumonia

questions.explanation:
Oral candidiasis is seen in stage 3, not stage 4 of HIV. The following conditions are included in the WHO stage IV of HIV: • HIV wasting syndrome (Slim disease) • HIV encephalopathy • HIV-associated nephropathy or cardiomyopathy • Infections: • Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (previously known as Pneumocystis carinii) • Chronic herpes simplex infection, cytomegalovirus disease • Oesophageal/ tracheal candidiasis • Extrapulmonary TB or disseminated M. avium infection • CNS toxoplasmosis • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis • Chronic cryptosporidiosis or isosporiasis • Disseminated fungal infections (histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis) • Recurrent severe bacterial pneumonia or septicemia • Atypical disseminated leishmaniasis • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy • Neoplasms: • Kaposi sarcoma • Lymphoma (cerebral or B cell non-Hodgkin) • Invasive cervical carcinoma 310 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 45-year man with a high-risk sexual history now presents with prolonged fever for the past 
1.5 months. On examination, the following finding is noted. Which one of the following 
additional features is re†uired to diagnose this patient with AIDS?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suspicious for HIV infection. As per the WHO definition, the presence 
of chronic diarrhea > 1 month is needed to diagnose this patient with AIDS. The WHO clinical definition is used for AIDS surveillance in the clinical setting. Patients > 12 
years of age are said to have AIDS if they have at least 2 major and 1 minor signs, provided other 
clinically similar conditions are be ruled out. Major signs: • Weight loss  10% of body weight • Chronic diarrhea > 1 month • Prolonged fever for > 1 month (intermittent or constant) Minor signs: • A persistent cough > 1 month • Generalized pruritic dermatitis • History of herpes zoster • Oropharyngeal candidiasis • Chronic progressive or disseminated herpes simplex infection • Generalized lymphadenopathy For surveillance purposes, the presence of either of the following is also considered sufficient to 
diagnose AIDS: • Generalized Kaposi's sarcoma • Cryptococcal meningitis

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the epidemiology of HIV?

options.a: HIV infected infants and children do not progress rapidly to AIDS
options.b: Seminal secretions are more infectious than vaginal secretion
options.c: People are infectious during the window period
options.d: HIV prevalence has not exceeded 5% in any subpopulation

questions.explanation: Infants and children infected with HIV progress rapidly to AIDS. Semen is more infectious than vaginal or cervical fluids as it has a higher concentration of HIV. HIV-infected patients are highly infectious during: • Window period (very early stages before antibody production) • Advanced stages of infection (due to higher levels of viremia) HIV prevalence has consistently remained < 5% in all defined subpopulations.

questions.question:
Question 7: 301 
Sold by @itachibot In individuals exposed to HIV, within how many hours should prophylaxis be initiated?
questions.explanation:
Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV should ideally be initiated within 72 hours. It is recommended 
that it be started as even as early as < 2 hours. 311 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A nurse sustained a needle stick injury while sampling the blood of a patient who is 
HIV-positive. Which of the following is incorrect?

options.a: Washing hands with soap and water
options.c: Measure baseline viral markers of health care worker immediately

questions.explanation:
Triple therapy (tenofovir 300mg + lamivudine 300mg + dolutegravir 50mg) is recommended for 
HIV post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), not monotherapy. Steps to be undertaken after a needlestick injury are: • Wash the wound and skin with water and soap. Do not scrub and avoid antiseptics. • Assess exposed individual: • Check baseline viral markers • Monitor for acute seroconversion illness within 3-6 weeks after exposure • If testing is positive, refer to ART center • Assess exposure source and determine the risk of transmission • Counseling and support • Initiate PEP at the earliest - preferably < 2 hours and ideally < 72 hours • 28-day prescription with drug information • HIV test at 3 months after exposure

questions.question:
Question 9: A resident doctor sustained a needlestick injury while sampling blood of a patient who is HIV 
positive. A decision is taken to offer him post-exposure prophylaxis. Which one of the 
following would be the best recommendation?
questions.explanation:
Triple therapy with tenofovir 300mg, lamivudine 300mg, and dolutegravir 50mg for 4 weeks is 
recommended for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Steps to be undertaken after a needlestick injury are: • Wash the wound and skin with water and soap. Do not scrub and avoid antiseptics. • Assess exposed individual: • Check baseline viral markers • Monitor for acute seroconversion illness within 3-6 weeks after exposure • If testing is positive, refer to ART center • Assess exposure source and determine the risk of transmission • Counseling and support • Initiate PEP at the earliest - preferably < 2 hours and ideally < 72 hours • 28-day prescription with drug information • HIV test at 3 months after exposure 312 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following HIV-infected patients would you start on cotrimoxazole prophylaxis?

options.a: A 24-year-old pregnant woman with WHO stage 2 disease.
options.b: A 47-year-old man in a malaria-endemic area with WHO stage 1 disease
options.c: A 2-week-old HIV-exposed infant who is being exclusively breastfed
options.d: A 7-year-old girl with a CD4 count of 400 cells/cubic mm

questions.explanation:
All HIV infected adults and children in malaria-endemic areas should be given cotrimoxazole 
prophylaxis regardless of CD4 count or WHO clinical stage. Cotrimoxazole is also indicated in areas with a low prevalence of malaria as shown below: Age group

questions.question:
Question 11: A 45-year-old man with HIV is being screened for symptoms of TB. He reports no cough, 
fever, night sweats, or weight loss. What is the next step in management?

options.a: Start 5 mg/kg/day Isoniazid daily for 9 months
options.b: Prophylaxis does not need to be started
options.d: Start weekly dose of rifapentine + isoniazid for 3 months

questions.explanation:
The next step in management in this patient is to provide tuberculosis preventive therapy (TPT) 
with rifapentine+ isoniazid weekly for 3 months. According to the NTEP guidelines, TPT is indicated for the following groups: IGRA - interferon-gamma release assay; TST - tuberculin skin test; ATT - antituberculous therapy TPT is contraindicated under the following conditions: • Active TB • Active hepatitis • Peripheral neuropathy • Regular and heavy alcohol consumption Risk group

Question 12: Which of the following is true about the 2025 targets of the Global AIDS Strategy for 2021 to

questions.question:
Question 13: A 29-year-old man comes to you with complaints of painful swelling in his right groin, as 
shown below. He gives a history of 3-4 painless ulcers over his penis 4 weeks ago that had 
resolved on its own. What is the likely causative organism? 303 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing the groove sign of Greenblatt are suggestive 
of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The causative organism is Chlamydia trachomatis. LGV commonly presents with multiple small, painless ulcers on the genitalia that are often 
unrecognized and resolve spontaneously. This is followed by painful lymphadenopathy and bubo 
formation after 4-6 weeks. If left untreated, it can lead to extensive lymphatic damage, 
elephantiasis, and deformity of the genitalia. The treatment of choice is doxycycline.

questions.explanation:

questions.explanation:

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not a part of case detection in STDs?
questions.explanation:
Notification is not part of the case detection strategy for STDs. Case detection in STDs includes 
the following: • Screening • Contact tracing • Cluster testing

questions.question:
Question 17: A 32-year-old man is diagnosed with syphilis. On probing, he gives you the information of 
other people in the same sociosexual environment as him. You then refer all these people for 
testing. What is this method of case detection? 304 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This method of case detection is known as cluster testing. The methods employed in case detection of STDs are: • Screening - testing of apparently healthy volunteers from the general population for early 
detection of disease • Contact tracing - techni†ue by which the sexual partners of diagnosed patients are identified, 
located, investigated, and treated • Cluster testing - patients are asked to name other persons who move in the same socio-sexual 
environment, who are then tested

questions.question:
Question 18: A 29-year-old man with urethral discharge is treated with the grey kit. This treatment is 
effective for the control of which of the following organisms?
questions.explanation:
The grey kit is effective for the treatment of infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and 
Chlamydia trachomatis.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is false about the epidemiology of leprosy?

options.a: Increased prevalence in childhood indicates that the disease is active and spreading.
options.b: Multibacillary cases are the most infectious in the community
options.c: Bacterial load is highest in patients with tuberculoid leprosy
options.d: Seldom may be transmitted by insect vectors

questions.explanation:
The bacterial load is highest in patients with lepromatous leprosy. 1 gram of leproma contains as 
many as 2-7 billion bacilli. 316 
Sold by @itachibot Multibacillary cases (lepromatous and borderline lepromatous) are the most important source of 
infection in the community. Infection can occur at any age. In general, cases rise to a peak 
between 10-20 years of age and then fall. In endemic areas, the disease is ac†uired commonly 
during childhood. A high prevalence in this age group indicates that the disease is active and 
spreading. The organism may also be transmitted by insect vectors or by tattooing needles. However, this is 
not clinically significant.

questions.question: Question 20: Elimination of leprosy in India is defined as the prevalence of :
questions.explanation: Elimination of leprosy in India is defined as a prevalence of < 1 per 10,000.

questions.question:
Question 21: What is the prevalence of leprosy in India per 10,000? 305 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: The prevalence of leprosy in India is 0.41 per 10,000 as of March 2021.

questions.question: Question 22: The Ridley Jopling classification for leprosy uses which of the following parameters?
questions.explanation:
The Ridley Jopling classification uses clinical, bacteriological, immunological, and histological 
parameters.

questions.question:
Question 23: A pathologist is studying the split skin smears taken from 4 sites of a leprosy patient. The 
following findings are noted in the samples. What is the bacteriological index?
questions.explanation:
The bacteriological index (BI) of the given samples is 3.5 According to Ridley’s logarithmic scale, • 10 bacilli out of 100 oil immersion fields indicate an index of 1+ • > 1000 bacilli out of average fields imply an index of 6+ The bacteriological index is calculated by adding the index from each site examined and dividing 
the total by the number of sites examined. Hence, BI = (1+1+6+6) / 4 BI = 14/4 BI = 3.5

questions.question:
Question 24: The lepromin test was performed on a patient with suspected leprosy. When will you ask him 
to come back for interpretation of the test results?
questions.explanation:
317 
Sold by @itachibot The patient should be asked to come back after 48 hours and on the 21st day for interpretation of 
the test results. The lepromin test is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity and is the only method to study 
immunity in leprosy patients. It is performed by injecting 0.1ml of lepromin 
reagent intradermally into the inner aspect of the forearm. The following 2 reactions are observed: Early reaction of Fernandez

questions.question:
Question 25: Which of the following is false about the lepromin test? 306 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It is negative in most children in the first 4 months of life
options.b: It can be used as a diagnostic test
options.c: It is used to classify leprosy cases
options.d: False positive may be seen in those who underwent BCG vacination

questions.explanation:
The lepromin test is not a diagnostic test. It is only used to assess the immune status, classify the 
cases, and estimate the prognosis. The two main drawbacks of this test are: • False-positive results in those who received BCG vaccination • False-negative results in lepromatous and borderline lepromatous cases

questions.question:
Question 26: A group of public health workers is trying to identify trachoma cases at an ophthalmology 
camp. Which of the following is the best index to assess for trachoma inflammation?

options.a: Follicles on the upper tarsal conjuctiva
options.d: Vascular pannus at the superior limbus

questions.explanation:
In epidemiological studies, the upper tarsal conjunctiva is the best index of trachomatous 
inflammation in the eye. For the purpose of diagnosis, any 2 of the following diagnostic criteria must be present: • Follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva • Limbal follicles and Herbert's pits • Typical conjunctival scarring (trichiasis and entropion) • Vascular pannus, most marked at the superior limbus The following image shows follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva seen in trachomatous 
inflammation. 318 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 27: Which of the following is true about the organisms causing trachoma?

options.a: Morax- Axenfeld bacillus is the most widespread
options.b: Gonococcus is the most dangerous organism contributing to the disease process
options.c: Koch-Weeks bacillus is the most innocuous
options.d: C. trachomatis type D commonly causes permanent visual damage

questions.explanation:
Gonococcus is the most dangerous organism contributing to the disease process in trachoma. Classic endemic trachoma is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis types A, B, C. Other pathogenic 
organisms that contribute to the disease process are: • Morax-Axenfeld diplobacillus - most innocuous • Kochs-Weeks bacillus - most widespread • Gonococcus - most dangerous The types D-K of C. trachomatis are sexually transmitted and cause inclusion conjunctivitis. It 
rarely causes permanent vision loss.

questions.question: Question 28: The elimination of neonatal tetanus is defined as:
questions.explanation:
The elimination of neonatal tetanus is defined as <1 case per 1000 live births in every 
district. Maternal and neonatal tetanus (MNT) was eliminated in India in 2015. Since July 2018, TT vaccines have been replaced by the Td vaccine for dual protection.

questions.question:
Question 29: Which of the following diseases is called the 8th day disease? 307 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Neonatal tetanus is known as the 8th-day disease. This is because the clinical features are often 
seen after the 7th day after birth due to infection of the umbilical cord. Option A: Trench fever is also called the 5-day fever. 319 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Pertussis is called the 100-day cough. Option D: Scarlet fever is also known as the 2nd disease.

questions.question:
Question 30: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the casualty a few hours after being injured by a rusty knife. 
According to her parents, her course of tetanus vaccination was completed 7 years ago. What 
is the next best step in management?

options.a: Smoking can cause sudden death from CHD.
options.b: Filters in cigarettes are protective against the development of CHD.
options.c: Risk of developing CHD 10-20 years after the cessation of smoking is equal in smokers and non
options.d: Degree of risk of developing CHD is directly related to the number of cigarettes smoked per

questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a contaminated wound in a patient who received complete 
immunization against tetanus 7 years ago. She comes under category B of tetanus immunization 
and must be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid alone. The WHO recommends a 3-dose primary vaccination series with tetanus-diphtheria-containing 
vaccine followed by 3 booster doses. Ideally, there should be at least 4 years between booster 
doses. 320 
Sold by @itachibot Non-Communicable Diseases - Cardiovascular Diseases and Diabetes
